question.title: Getting the name of the currently executing method
question.body: Is there a way to get the name of the currently executing method in Java?

answers.body:
For those who must use Java 8:

I'm forced to use Java 8. I needed a solution for constructing LOGGER strings that bracket static and instance methods with a "Begin"/"End" pair using LOGGER.info . I also need to sometimes use LOGGER.warn. My project therefore defines a String logIdentifier at the start of each method.

In my project, every class is in a hierarchy rooted at It:

public class It implements PackageConstants {
  // ...
}

I combined several of the above answers with a static and an instance version on It as follows:

  public static String staticLogIdentifier() {
    Integer stackFrameIndex = LOG_IDENTIFIER_STACK_FRAME_INDEX; // Try 2
    final StackTraceElement stackFrame = Thread.currentThread().getStackTrace()[stackFrameIndex];
    final String canonicalClassName = stackFrame.getClassName();
    final String simpleClassName = canonicalClassName.substring(canonicalClassName.lastIndexOf('.') + 1, canonicalClassName.length());
    final String methodName = stackFrame.getMethodName();
    String logIdentifier = String.format("%sClass.%s", simpleClassName, methodName);
    return logIdentifier;
  }

  public String logIdentifier() {
    Integer stackFrameIndex = LOG_IDENTIFIER_STACK_FRAME_INDEX; // Try 2
    final StackTraceElement stackFrame = Thread.currentThread().getStackTrace()[stackFrameIndex];
    final String canonicalClassName = stackFrame.getClassName();
    final String simpleClassName = canonicalClassName.substring(canonicalClassName.lastIndexOf('.') + 1, canonicalClassName.length());
    final String methodName = stackFrame.getMethodName();
    String logIdentifier = String.format("%s.%s", simpleClassName, methodName);
    return logIdentifier;
  }

These use a constant that I define in an interface that the root implements:

public interface PackageConstants {

  public static final Integer LOG_IDENTIFIER_STACK_FRAME_INDEX = 2;

}

I empirically confirmed that 2 is the correct value for my project environment.

In each descendant, I bracket each static method with the following:

  public static void someStaticMethod() {
    String logIdentifier = staticLogIdentifier();
    LOGGER.info(String.format("%s: Begin", logIdentifier));

    //...

    LOGGER.info(String.format("%s: End", logIdentifier));
  }

Similarly, I bracket each instance method with the following:

  public void someInstanceMethod() {
    String logIdentifier = this.logIdentifier();
    LOGGER.info(String.format("%s: Begin", logIdentifier));

    //...

    LOGGER.info(String.format("%s: End", logIdentifier));
  }

This does EXACTLY what my project needs!

This saves my team countless hours of time chasing down problems that result from relying on hard-coded strings in the various methods of this large project.

I really appreciate the answers and comments in this entry -- it exemplifies why this site is such a valuable resource.
